poem:
### Scouse Festivity

In Liverpool's stage,  
Scrooge, unbuttoned—  
a chuckle in his bones,  
dances to the sly beat—  
"I'm Too Sexy"  
echoes like jingle bells,  
a mane of mirth,  
while festive lights flicker,  
candor winks at tradition—  
the city's heart boasts  
laughter's glow,  
wrapped in stray beats,  
an unheeded joy,  
caroling cheekily  
through the night.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Scouse Christmas Carol review – knockabout comedy with a potty mouth Whether it’s Paul Hilton at London’s Old Vic this winter or Marti Pellow in Glasgow next year, you’re never far from a Scrooge during the festive season. Only one of them, however, will strip down to his long johns as he sings I’m Too Sexy by Right Said Fred. At Liverpool’s Royal Court they do things differently. With his brushed back mane of". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
